{
    "id": 101073308,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/26332",
    "body": "We love using git as our ext_pillar... we also love having out minions dynamically decide which pillars they have access to. We do this with the following pillar top.sls \n\n``` saltstack\nbase:\n\n  '*':\n{%- set pillars = salt['grains.get']('pillars', '') %}\n{%- if pillars %}\n    {%- for pillar in pillars.get('base',[]) %}\n    - base.{{ pillar }}\n    {%- endfor %}\n    {%- for pillar in pillars.get('all',[]) %}\n    - base.{{ pillar }}\n    {%- endfor %}\n{% endif %}\n```\n\nSo basically we load the grains and decide which pillars should be loaded to a minion. It works great, but as we start scaling I am seeing things get slower and slower. The above is repeated for envrionments dev, stg, prd. \n\nIn my logs I see a ton of this.... \n\n`2015-08-14 18:26:31,198 [salt.pillar.git_pillar][DEBUG   ][1151] Updating fileserver for git_pillar module`\n\nIt seems like for every run the salt-master is rebuilding the pillar for each machine running a job and each environment. \n\nThis makes things pretty slow. I was hoping that there was some option to do cacheing or speed up this process. Otherwise we will probably start looking at other ext_pillar solutions. \n",

    "body": "**Description**\r\nWhen not connected to active directory the function _get_sam_name_  in the module _utils.win_functions_ returns bad output. In particular if this function is passed a user name that isn't known about locally, like _my_domain\\user_name_, it will return a completely invalid username like _my_computer_name\\my_domain\\user_name_.\r\n\r\n**Setup**\r\nHere is a state formula called _test.sls_\r\n```\r\nadmins present:\r\n    group.present:\r\n       - name: Administrators\r\n       - addusers:\r\n           - AD\\random_user\r\n```\r\n\r\nWhen you do the test make sure _random_user_ is some some active directory user which the local machine doesn't know about. That way the bug won't get bypassed because of caching. Also make sure that AD is actually the name of your active directory domain.\r\n\r\n**Steps to Reproduce the behavior**\r\n\r\n1. Be sure that you are not connected to your domain controller.\r\n\r\n2. Run the following command on your windows minion.\r\n\r\n```\r\nsalt-call state.apply test.sls\r\n```\r\n\r\nIf the bug is reproduced you will see this big stack trace:\r\n\r\n```\r\n An exception occurred in this state: Traceback (most recent call last):\r\n                File \"c:\\salt\\bin\\lib\\site-packages\\salt-3000-py3.5.egg\\salt\\modules\\win_groupadd.py\", line 278, in adduser\r\n                  group_obj.Add('WinNT://' + username.replace('\\\\', '/'))\r\n                File \"<COMObject <unknown>>\", line 2, in Add\r\n              pywintypes.com_error: (-2147352567, 'Exception occurred.', (0, 'Active Directory', 'An unknown directory object was requested\\r\\n', None, 0, -2147463164), None)\r\n              \r\n              During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:\r\n              \r\n              Traceback (most recent call last):\r\n                File \"c:\\salt\\bin\\lib\\site-packages\\salt-3000-py3.5.egg\\salt\\state.py\", line 1981, in call\r\n                  **cdata['kwargs'])\r\n                File \"c:\\salt\\bin\\lib\\site-packages\\salt-3000-py3.5.egg\\salt\\loader.py\", line 1977, in wrapper\r\n                  return f(*args, **kwargs)\r\n                File \"c:\\salt\\bin\\lib\\site-packages\\salt-3000-py3.5.egg\\salt\\states\\group.py\", line 220, in present\r\n                  __salt__['group.adduser'](name, user)\r\n                File \"c:\\salt\\bin\\lib\\site-packages\\salt-3000-py3.5.egg\\salt\\modules\\win_groupadd.py\", line 285, in adduser\r\n                  username, name, win32api.FormatMessage(exc.excepinfo[5]))\r\n              pywintypes.error: (317, 'FormatMessageW', 'The system cannot find message text for message number 0x%1 in the message file for %2.')\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe stacktrace happened because _win_groupadd.adduser_ is being asked to process a user name like _my_computername\\my_domain_name\\user_name_ as a consequence of _get_sam_name_ returning bad output.\r\n\r\n**Expected behavior**\r\nIf the minion needs to talk to active directory but cannot, we should have a clean error, one way or another. I'm agnostic about what perfect behaviour should be. My position is only that the status quo is not good.\r\n\r\n**Versions Report**\r\n<details><summary>salt --versions-report</summary>\r\n\r\n```\r\nSalt Version:\r\n           Salt: 3000.1\r\n \r\nDependency Versions:\r\n           cffi: 1.12.3\r\n       cherrypy: Not Installed\r\n       dateutil: 2.8.0\r\n      docker-py: Not Installed\r\n          gitdb: 2.0.3\r\n      gitpython: 3.0.2\r\n         Jinja2: 2.10.1\r\n        libgit2: 0.28.2\r\n       M2Crypto: Not Installed\r\n           Mako: Not Installed\r\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\r\n msgpack-python: 0.6.2\r\n   mysql-python: Not Installed\r\n      pycparser: 2.14\r\n       pycrypto: 2.6.1\r\n   pycryptodome: Not Installed\r\n         pygit2: 0.28.2\r\n         Python: 3.7.6 (default, Jan 30 2020, 09:44:41)\r\n   python-gnupg: Not Installed\r\n         PyYAML: 3.13\r\n          PyZMQ: 18.0.2\r\n          smmap: 2.0.3\r\n        timelib: Not Installed\r\n        Tornado: 4.5.3\r\n            ZMQ: 4.3.2\r\n \r\nSystem Versions:\r\n           dist: fedora 31 Thirty One\r\n         locale: UTF-8\r\n        machine: x86_64\r\n        release: 5.5.17-200.fc31.x86_64\r\n         system: Linux\r\n        version: Fedora 31 Thirty One\r\n```\r\n</details>\r\n\r\n**Additional context**\r\nI am running salt v 3000 (py3) on the minion.\r\n",

{
    "body": [
        "**Description**
When not connected to active directory the function _get_sam_name_  in the module _utils.win_functions_ returns bad output. In particular if this function is passed a user name that isn't known about locally, like _my_domain\user_name_, it will return a completely invalid username like _my_computer_name\my_domain\user_name_.

**Setup**
Here is a state formula called _test.sls_
```
admins present:
    group.present:
       - name: Administrators
       - addusers:
           - AD\random_user
```

When you do the test make sure _random_user_ is some some active directory user which the local machine doesn't know about. That way the bug won't get bypassed because of caching. Also make sure that AD is actually the name of your active directory domain.

**Steps to Reproduce the behavior**

1. Be sure that you are not connected to your domain controller.

2. Run the following command on your windows minion.

```
salt-call state.apply test.sls
```

If the bug is reproduced you will see this big stack trace:

```
 An exception occurred in this state: Traceback (most recent call last):
                File "c:\salt\bin\lib\site-packages\salt-3000-py3.5.egg\salt\modules\win_groupadd.py", line 278, in adduser
                  group_obj.Add('WinNT://' + username.replace('\\', '/'))
                File "<COMObject <unknown>>", line 2, in Add
              pywintypes.com_error: (-2147352567, 'Exception occurred.', (0, 'Active Directory', 'An unknown directory object was requested\r\n', None, 0, -2147463164), None)
              
              During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:
              
              Traceback (most recent call last):
                File "c:\salt\bin\lib\site-packages\salt-3000-py3.5.egg\salt\state.py", line 1981, in call
                  **cdata['kwargs'])
                File "c:\salt\bin\lib\site-packages\salt-3000-py3.5.egg\salt\loader.py", line 1977, in wrapper
                  return f(*args, **kwargs)
                File "c:\salt\bin\lib\site-packages\salt-3000-py3.5.egg\salt\states\group.py", line 220, in present
                  __salt__['group.adduser'](name, user)
                File "c:\salt\bin\lib\site-packages\salt-3000-py3.5.egg\salt\modules\win_groupadd.py", line 285, in adduser
                  username, name, win32api.FormatMessage(exc.excepinfo[5]))
              pywintypes.error: (317, 'FormatMessageW', 'The system cannot find message text for message number 0x%1 in the message file for %2.')
```

The stacktrace happened because _win_groupadd.adduser_ is being asked to process a user name like _my_computername\my_domain_name\user_name_ as a consequence of _get_sam_name_ returning bad output.

**Expected behavior**
If the minion needs to talk to active directory but cannot, we should have a clean error, one way or another. I'm agnostic about what perfect behaviour should be. My position is only that the status quo is not good.

**Versions Report**
<details><summary>salt --versions-report</summary>

```
Salt Version:
           Salt: 3000.1
 
Dependency Versions:
           cffi: 1.12.3
       cherrypy: Not Installed
       dateutil: 2.8.0
      docker-py: Not Installed
          gitdb: 2.0.3
      gitpython: 3.0.2
         Jinja2: 2.10.1
        libgit2: 0.28.2
       M2Crypto: Not Installed
           Mako: Not Installed
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.6.2
   mysql-python: Not Installed
      pycparser: 2.14
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
   pycryptodome: Not Installed
         pygit2: 0.28.2
         Python: 3.7.6 (default, Jan 30 2020, 09:44:41)
   python-gnupg: Not Installed
         PyYAML: 3.13
          PyZMQ: 18.0.2
          smmap: 2.0.3
        timelib: Not Installed
        Tornado: 4.5.3
            ZMQ: 4.3.2
 
System Versions:
           dist: fedora 31 Thirty One
         locale: UTF-8
        machine: x86_64
        release: 5.5.17-200.fc31.x86_64
         system: Linux
        version: Fedora 31 Thirty One
```
</details>

**Additional context**
I am running salt v 3000 (py3) on the minion.
"

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "Initially: "debian_ip ifupdown /etc/network/interfaces options for tunnels, ipv6, and dns-search"

[EDIT]

**Documentation**

_Ubuntu ifupdown Docs_

Here are the (ubuntu) docs for /etc/network/interfaces (`pkg: ifupdown`).
- http://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/trusty/en/man5/interfaces.5.html
- http://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/precise/en/man5/interfaces.5.html
- http://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/lucid/en/man5/interfaces.5.html

_Salt Docs_
- http://docs.saltstack.com/en/latest/topics/releases/2014.1.0.html#network-management-for-debian-ubuntu
- http://docs.saltstack.com/en/latest/ref/modules/all/salt.modules.debian_ip.html#module-salt.modules.debian_ip
-  https://github.com/saltstack/salt/pull/9662 (iptables ipv6)

**Sources**
- https://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/develop/salt/modules/debian_ip.py
- https://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/develop/salt/templates/debian_ip/debian_eth.jinja
- https://github.com/westurner/salt/compare/debian_network_config

**Tickets**

I don't see any other tickets for e.g. tunnels, ipv6, or dns-search (as utilized by resolvconf) in debian_ip:

---

[EDIT]

**BUG**:
- [x] Unclosed file handles (-> `file.open` -> `with salt.utils.flopen`)
- [x] Don't write /etc/default/networking on Ubuntu >= 12.04
  - get_network_settings returns templated output to compare with templated output with difflib.unified_diff (in https://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/develop/salt/states/network.py) and thus runs on every salt invocation w/ Ubuntu <= 12.04
  - https://github.com/saltstack/salt/commit/c70c2057b8dcf56d0948d1e61d94775e6dda992b
- \* /etc/resolv.conf is overwritten when resolvconf is installed (this may be a documentation issue)

**PERF**:
- [x] Simplify /etc/network/interfaces parser logic

**TST**:
- [ ] Handle 'TODOs'
- [ ] Write tests
- [ ] Further (manual) testing on other platforms
  - I've run this manually on one platform a bunch of times.

**ENH**:
- [x] Add (rework/complete) debian ipv6 options
- [x] Add Adds dns-search option
- [x] Add wireless-\* options
- [x] Add wpa-\* options
- [x] Add basic seting validations

**RLS**:
- [x] Merge: https://github.com/garethgreenaway/salt/commit/d7884d5faa1ba2e85a78dacbf1857607dc959768
- [x] Release: https://github.com/saltstack/salt/releases/tag/v2014.7:
  - https://github.com/saltstack/salt/commits/2014.7/salt/modules/debian_ip.py
  - https://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/develop/salt/templates/debian_ip/debian_eth.jinja
"

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "Using this state:

```
{%- for city in cities %}
{{ dbdir }}/{{city.iata}}/router.db:
  file.managed:
    - source: salt://rancid/templates/router.db.jinja
    - template: jinja
    - user: rancid
    - group: rancid
    - mode: 644
    - context:
        devices: {{ city.devices }}
    - defaults:
        matching:
          junos: juniper
          iosxr: cisco-xr
          nxos: cisco-nx
    - require:
      - cmd: run-rancid-cvs
{% endfor -%}
```

/srv/salt/rancid/templates/router.db.jinja:

```
# {{ pillar.get('managed_by_salt_message', '') }}
{{ devices }}
```

While this is working perfectly on 2015.8.1 (and previous):

```
# MANAGED BY SALT -- DO NOT MODIFY
[{'name': 'edge01.ord02', 'type': 'router', 'ip': '141.101.73.1', 'region': 'NA', 'os': 'junos'}, {'status': 'up', 'ip': '141.101.73.18', 'os': 'junos', 'name': 'core01.ord02', 'type': 'switch'}, {'status': 'up', 'ip': '141.101.73.21', 'os': 'pluribus', 'name': 'core02.ord02', 'type': 'switch'}, {'status': 'up', 'ip': '141.101.73.22', 'os': 'junos', 'name': 'core03.ord02', 'type': 'switch'}, {'status': 'down', 'ip': '141.101.73.34', 'os': 'nxos', 'name': 'core04.ord02', 'type': 'switch'}, {'status': 'up', 'ip': '141.101.73.36', 'os': 'nxos', 'name': 'core05.ord02', 'type': 'switch'}, {'status': 'down', 'ip': '141.101.73.20', 'os': 'junos', 'name': 'ms02.ord02', 'type': 'switch'}, {'status': 'up', 'ip': '141.101.73.35', 'os': 'junos', 'name': 'ms04.ord02', 'type': 'switch'}, {'status': 'up', 'ip': '141.101.73.37', 'os': 'junos', 'name': 'ms05.ord02', 'type': 'switch'}]
```

after fetching latest 2015.8, this renders as:

```
# MANAGED BY SALT -- DO NOT MODIFY
[{u"u'os'": u"u'junos'", u"u'type'": u"u'router'", u"u'region'": u"u'NA'", u"u'ip'": u"u'141.101.73.1'", u"u'name'": u"u'edge01.ord02'"}, {u"u'os'": u"u'junos'", u"u'type'": u"u'switch'", u"u'ip'": u"u'141.101.73.18'", u"u'status'": u"u'up'", u"u'name'": u"u'core01.ord02'"}, {u"u'os'": u"u'pluribus'", u"u'type'": u"u'switch'", u"u'ip'": u"u'141.101.73.21'", u"u'status'": u"u'up'", u"u'name'": u"u'core02.ord02'"}, {u"u'os'": u"u'junos'", u"u'type'": u"u'switch'", u"u'ip'": u"u'141.101.73.22'", u"u'status'": u"u'up'", u"u'name'": u"u'core03.ord02'"}, {u"u'os'": u"u'nxos'", u"u'type'": u"u'switch'", u"u'ip'": u"u'141.101.73.34'", u"u'status'": u"u'down'", u"u'name'": u"u'core04.ord02'"}, {u"u'os'": u"u'nxos'", u"u'type'": u"u'switch'", u"u'ip'": u"u'141.101.73.36'", u"u'status'": u"u'up'", u"u'name'": u"u'core05.ord02'"}, {u"u'os'": u"u'junos'", u"u'type'": u"u'switch'", u"u'ip'": u"u'141.101.73.20'", u"u'status'": u"u'down'", u"u'name'": u"u'ms02.ord02'"}, {u"u'os'": u"u'junos'", u"u'type'": u"u'switch'", u"u'ip'": u"u'141.101.73.35'", u"u'status'": u"u'up'", u"u'name'": u"u'ms04.ord02'"}, {u"u'os'": u"u'junos'", u"u'type'": u"u'switch'", u"u'ip'": u"u'141.101.73.37'", u"u'status'": u"u'up'", u"u'name'": u"u'ms05.ord02'"}]
```

note the double unicode quoting, this is breaking everything.

I identified the culprit commit to be https://github.com/saltstack/salt/commit/fadb954676f2627d7211e8fa723de65b539c9a7d 
cc @basepi

    "body": "Not sure, but shouldn't `ca.key` be `www.key` here?\r\nhttps://docs.saltstack.com/en/latest/ref/states/all/salt.states.x509.html#salt.states.x509.private_key_managed\r\n```\r\n/etc/pki/www.key:\r\n  x509.private_key_managed:\r\n    - bits: 4096\r\n    - new: True\r\n    {% if salt['file.file_exists']('/etc/pki/ca.key') -%}\r\n    - prereq:\r\n      - x509: /etc/pki/www.crt\r\n    {%- endif %}\r\n```\r\n",

    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/7173",
    "body": "Numpy has [hacks](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/numpy/core/src/npymath/npy_math.c.src) to work around bad/missing/old platform math library implementations. It has been mentioned [a](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/6976) [few](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/6081) [times](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/6712) that the compatibly-licensed [openlibm](http://julialang.org/openlibm/) could be used instead, so I'm opening a separate github issue for that idea.\n",

Minions running: salt-minion 2014.1.10 (Hydrogen)
Master running: salt-master 2014.1.10 (Hydrogen)

OS: Debian Jessie

Master config:

```
# Allow salt to execute anything
client_acl:
  salt:
    - .*
    - test.ping

file_roots:
  base:
    - /home/salt/src/config/states

pillar_roots:
  base:
    - /home/salt/src/config/pillar
```

The master is running as root, and root can send commands:

The salt user cannot use salt to send commands, and reports:
 "Failed to connect to the Master, is the Salt Master running?"

```
salt -l debug "*" cmd.run "uptime"
```

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "Setup:

Minions running: salt-minion 2014.1.10 (Hydrogen)
Master running: salt-master 2014.1.10 (Hydrogen)

OS: Debian Jessie

Master config:

```
# Allow salt to execute anything
client_acl:
  salt:
    - .*
    - test.ping

file_roots:
  base:
    - /home/salt/src/config/states

pillar_roots:
  base:
    - /home/salt/src/config/pillar
```

The master is running as root, and root can send commands:

The salt user cannot use salt to send commands, and reports:
 "Failed to connect to the Master, is the Salt Master running?"

```
salt -l debug "*" cmd.run "uptime"
[DEBUG   ] Reading configuration from /etc/salt/master
[DEBUG   ] Missing configuration file: /home/salt/.saltrc
[DEBUG   ] Configuration file path: /etc/salt/master
[DEBUG   ] Reading configuration from /etc/salt/master
[DEBUG   ] Missing configuration file: /home/salt/.saltrc
[DEBUG   ] LocalClientEvent PUB socket URI: ipc:///var/run/salt/master/master_event_pub.ipc
[DEBUG   ] LocalClientEvent PULL socket URI: ipc:///var/run/salt/master/master_event_pull.ipc
Failed to connect to the Master, is the Salt Master running?
[DEBUG   ] Loaded no_out as virtual quiet
[DEBUG   ] Loaded json_out as virtual json
[DEBUG   ] Loaded yaml_out as virtual yaml
[DEBUG   ] Loaded pprint_out as virtual pprint
```

Salt version says:

```
salt --versions-report
           Salt: 2014.1.10
         Python: 2.7.8 (default, Aug 23 2014, 21:00:50)
         Jinja2: 2.7.3
       M2Crypto: 0.21.1
 msgpack-python: 0.4.2
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
         PyYAML: 3.11
          PyZMQ: 14.3.1
            ZMQ: 4.0.4
```

Full debug output from running `salt-master -l debug`

    "id": 133212078,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/31154",
    "body": "Hello !\n\nI'm currently testing the ini_manage state (and the related module) in the develop branch, and noticed some performance degradation.\nIn my setup, a dry-run takes about 50s, where it used to take about 6s with the \"old\" (2015.08.5) version.\n## version\n\nServer:\n\n```\nSalt Version:\n           Salt: 2015.8.4\n\nDependency Versions:\n         Jinja2: 2.7.3\n       M2Crypto: 0.21.1\n           Mako: 1.0.0\n         PyYAML: 3.11\n          PyZMQ: 14.4.0\n         Python: 2.7.9 (default, Mar  1 2015, 12:57:24)\n           RAET: Not Installed\n        Tornado: 4.2.1\n            ZMQ: 4.0.5\n           cffi: 0.8.6\n       cherrypy: 3.5.0\n       dateutil: 2.2\n          gitdb: 0.5.4\n      gitpython: 0.3.2 RC1\n          ioflo: Not Installed\n        libgit2: Not Installed\n        libnacl: Not Installed\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\n msgpack-python: 0.4.2\n   mysql-python: 1.2.3\n      pycparser: 2.10\n       pycrypto: 2.6.1\n         pygit2: Not Installed\n   python-gnupg: Not Installed\n          smmap: 0.8.2\n        timelib: Not Installed\n\nSystem Versions:\n           dist: debian 8.1 \n        machine: x86_64\n        release: 3.16.0-4-amd64\n         system: debian 8.1 \n```\n\nWhile using  ini_manage state as of eb19140cc5caaa7e6664a9a99389f958b307e5e9 and ini_manage module as of 6339d7bfd9d4e1b9fe60b8082aa26138ae9add34\nThese 2 versions are in the current develop branch, and I only backported these 2 one, by placing them in _states/ and _modules/ directory of the fileserver.\n\n(If you try to reproduce, It also seems to be an unrelated issue with the ini_manage module and the way it handles non-string values, and will make a separate issue about that)\n### Run duration\n\nWith 2015.0.5 ini_manage (dry run unsupported)\n\n```\nSucceeded: 194 (unchanged=4)\nFailed:      0\n--------------\nTotal states run:     194\nTotal run time:     8.180 s\n\n```\n\nWith the \"develop\" ini_manage\n\n```\nSucceeded: 194\nFailed:      0\n--------------\nTotal states run:     194\nTotal run time:    56.227 s\n```\n## Investigation\n\nI've looked at the previous commits, and saw that ini_manage now support testing changes when test=true is specified (from commit bf95bf9e5532c0bd868eb6968eaea88cd1279e72), by doing this\n\n```\n    if __opts__['test']:\n        ret['result'] = True\n        ret['comment'] = ''\n        for section in sections or {}:\n            section_name = ' in section ' + section if section != 'DEFAULT_IMPLICIT' else ''\n            for key in sections[section]:\n                cur_value = __salt__['ini.get_option'](name, section, key)\n                if cur_value == str(sections[section][key]):\n                    ret['comment'] += 'Key {0}{1} unchanged.\\n'.format(key, section_name)\n                    continue\n                ret['comment'] += 'Changed key {0}{1}.\\n'.format(key, section_name)\n                ret['result'] = None\n        return ret\n\n```\n\nThat's great, but it results in a large amount of `__salt__['ini.get_option']()` calls if we manage multiple ini key , which seems to be a bit slow.\nBy replacing all the `__salt__['ini.get_option']()` call with a `__salt__['ini.get_section']()` loading all the section before iterating on it, my dry-run takes ~8s (instead of 56s).\n\n```\n if __opts__['test']:\n        ret['result'] = True\n        ret['comment'] = ''\n        for section in sections or {}:\n            section_name = ' in section ' + section if section != 'DEFAULT_IMPLICIT' else ''\n            curr_section = __salt__['ini.get_section'](name, section)\n            for key in sections[section]:\n                cur_value = curr_section.get(key)\n                if cur_value == str(sections[section][key]):\n                    ret['comment'] += 'Key {0}{1} unchanged.\\n'.format(key, section_name)\n                    continue\n                ret['comment'] += 'Changed key {0}{1}.\\n'.format(key, section_name)\n                ret['result'] = None\n        if ret['comment'] == '':\n            ret['comment'] = 'No changes detected.'\n        return ret\n```\n\nI will continue testing, and make a PR with these changes if you guys think it's worth it.\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "Hello !

I'm currently testing the ini_manage state (and the related module) in the develop branch, and noticed some performance degradation.
In my setup, a dry-run takes about 50s, where it used to take about 6s with the "old" (2015.08.5) version.
## version

Server:

```
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2015.8.4

Dependency Versions:
         Jinja2: 2.7.3
       M2Crypto: 0.21.1
           Mako: 1.0.0
         PyYAML: 3.11
          PyZMQ: 14.4.0
         Python: 2.7.9 (default, Mar  1 2015, 12:57:24)
           RAET: Not Installed
        Tornado: 4.2.1
            ZMQ: 4.0.5
           cffi: 0.8.6
       cherrypy: 3.5.0
       dateutil: 2.2
          gitdb: 0.5.4
      gitpython: 0.3.2 RC1
          ioflo: Not Installed
        libgit2: Not Installed
        libnacl: Not Installed
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.4.2
   mysql-python: 1.2.3
      pycparser: 2.10
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
         pygit2: Not Installed
   python-gnupg: Not Installed
          smmap: 0.8.2
        timelib: Not Installed

System Versions:
           dist: debian 8.1 
        machine: x86_64
        release: 3.16.0-4-amd64
         system: debian 8.1 
```

While using  ini_manage state as of eb19140cc5caaa7e6664a9a99389f958b307e5e9 and ini_manage module as of 6339d7bfd9d4e1b9fe60b8082aa26138ae9add34
These 2 versions are in the current develop branch, and I only backported these 2 one, by placing them in _states/ and _modules/ directory of the fileserver.

(If you try to reproduce, It also seems to be an unrelated issue with the ini_manage module and the way it handles non-string values, and will make a separate issue about that)
### Run duration

With 2015.0.5 ini_manage (dry run unsupported)

```
Succeeded: 194 (unchanged=4)
Failed:      0
--------------
Total states run:     194
Total run time:     8.180 s

```

With the "develop" ini_manage

```
Succeeded: 194
Failed:      0
--------------
Total states run:     194
Total run time:    56.227 s
```
## Investigation

I've looked at the previous commits, and saw that ini_manage now support testing changes when test=true is specified (from commit bf95bf9e5532c0bd868eb6968eaea88cd1279e72), by doing this

```
    if __opts__['test']:
        ret['result'] = True
        ret['comment'] = ''
        for section in sections or {}:
            section_name = ' in section ' + section if section != 'DEFAULT_IMPLICIT' else ''
            for key in sections[section]:
                cur_value = __salt__['ini.get_option'](name, section, key)
                if cur_value == str(sections[section][key]):
                    ret['comment'] += 'Key {0}{1} unchanged.\n'.format(key, section_name)
                    continue
                ret['comment'] += 'Changed key {0}{1}.\n'.format(key, section_name)
                ret['result'] = None
        return ret

```

That's great, but it results in a large amount of `__salt__['ini.get_option']()` calls if we manage multiple ini key , which seems to be a bit slow.
By replacing all the `__salt__['ini.get_option']()` call with a `__salt__['ini.get_section']()` loading all the section before iterating on it, my dry-run takes ~8s (instead of 56s).

```
 if __opts__['test']:
        ret['result'] = True
        ret['comment'] = ''
        for section in sections or {}:
            section_name = ' in section ' + section if section != 'DEFAULT_IMPLICIT' else ''
            curr_section = __salt__['ini.get_section'](name, section)
            for key in sections[section]:
                cur_value = curr_section.get(key)
                if cur_value == str(sections[section][key]):
                    ret['comment'] += 'Key {0}{1} unchanged.\n'.format(key, section_name)
                    continue
                ret['comment'] += 'Changed key {0}{1}.\n'.format(key, section_name)
                ret['result'] = None
        if ret['comment'] == '':
            ret['comment'] = 'No changes detected.'
        return ret
```

I will continue testing, and make a PR with these changes if you guys think it's worth it.
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "ini_manage performance issue in dry-run"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",
            "description": "broken, incorrect, or confusing behavior"
        },
        {
            "name": "P2",
            "description": "Priority 2"
        },
        {
            "name": "Platform",
            "description": "Relates to OS, containers, platform-based utilities like FS, system based apps"

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question

`comments` in `pkgrepo.managed` does not behave as documented. The documentation states, "Anything supplied for this list will be saved in the repo configuration with a comment marker (#) in front." However, Salt does not behave this way; anything in the comments section is added WITHOUT a # in front. I am not sure if the behavior or the documentation is wrong, but they don't match.
### Setup
### Steps to Reproduce Issue

This state:

```
epel:
  pkgrepo.managed:
    - humanname: Extra Packages for Enterprise Linux 7 - $basearch
    - mirrorlist: https://mirrors.fedoraproject.org/metalink?repo=epel-7&arch=$basearch
    - comments:
        - 'baseurl=http://download.fedoraproject.org/pub/epel/7/$basearch'
    - gpgcheck: 1
    - gpgkey: file:///etc/pki/rpm-gpg/RPM-GPG-KEY-EPEL-7
    - priority: 3
```

Produces this repo file:

```
[epel]
priority=3
mirrorlist=https://mirrors.fedoraproject.org/metalink?repo=epel-7&arch=$basearch
name=Extra Packages for Enterprise Linux 7 - $basearch
gpgcheck=1
gpgkey=file:///etc/pki/rpm-gpg/RPM-GPG-KEY-EPEL-7
enabled=1
baseurl=http://download.fedoraproject.org/pub/epel/7/$basearch
```

Note that no # sign is placed in front of `baseurl`, so it is not actually a comment. You have to include the # sign in your state.
### Versions Report

```
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2016.3.1

Dependency Versions:
           cffi: Not Installed
       cherrypy: Not Installed
       dateutil: Not Installed
          gitdb: Not Installed
      gitpython: Not Installed
          ioflo: Not Installed
         Jinja2: 2.7.2
        libgit2: Not Installed
        libnacl: Not Installed
       M2Crypto: Not Installed
           Mako: Not Installed
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.4.6
   mysql-python: Not Installed
      pycparser: Not Installed
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
         pygit2: Not Installed
         Python: 2.7.5 (default, Nov 20 2015, 02:00:19)
   python-gnupg: Not Installed
         PyYAML: 3.11
          PyZMQ: 14.7.0
           RAET: Not Installed
          smmap: Not Installed
        timelib: Not Installed
        Tornado: 4.2.1
            ZMQ: 4.0.5

System Versions:
           dist: centos 7.2.1511 Core
        machine: x86_64
        release: 3.10.0-327.22.2.el7.x86_64
         system: Linux
        version: CentOS Linux 7.2.1511 Core
```
"
    ],

        "Incorrect behavior or documentation for comments in salt.states.pkgrepo.managed"

{
    "body": [
        "**Description**
Running salt-call slsutil.renderer is causing a freeze after the output. 

**Setup**
install salt and render a file with saltutil.renderer `salt-call slsutil.renderer` watch it stick and have to hit ctrl+c to get a prompt back.

**Steps to Reproduce the behavior**
`salt-call slsutil.renderer salt://test/init.sls` file doesn't need to exist. 

**Expected behavior**
salt-call exists after modules return.

**Screenshots**
If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

**Versions Report**
<details><summary>salt-call test.versions</summary>


```
local:
    Salt Version:
               Salt: 3001rc1

    Dependency Versions:
```

{
    "id": 105043411,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/11007",
    "body": "On master, as a small example:\n\n```\nIn [1]: df = pd.DataFrame([[1,2,3,4],[5,6,7,8]], columns=['A','B','A','B'])\n\nIn [2]: df\nOut[2]:\n   A  B  A  B\n0  1  2  3  4\n1  5  6  7  8\n\nIn [4]: df.to_excel('test_excel_duplicate_columns.xlsx')\n```\n\ngives:\n\n![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1020496/9700751/4cacf18e-540f-11e5-923b-e6d6689d569f.PNG)\n\nSo the values of columns 2 and 3 are swapped (not the column names)\n\nBTW, this happens both with .xlsx as .xls (openpyxl / xlsxwriter / xlwt)\n\nPossibly related: #10982, #10970\n",

{
    "body": [
        "On master, as a small example:

```
In [1]: df = pd.DataFrame([[1,2,3,4],[5,6,7,8]], columns=['A','B','A','B'])

In [2]: df
Out[2]:
   A  B  A  B
0  1  2  3  4
1  5  6  7  8

In [4]: df.to_excel('test_excel_duplicate_columns.xlsx')
```

gives:

![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1020496/9700751/4cacf18e-540f-11e5-923b-e6d6689d569f.PNG)

So the values of columns 2 and 3 are swapped (not the column names)

BTW, this happens both with .xlsx as .xls (openpyxl / xlsxwriter / xlwt)

Possibly related: #10982, #10970
"

    "id": 444559053,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/53041",
    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\r\n\r\nWhen using `salt.state` in an orchestrator, I get the following error:\r\n\r\n```\r\n----------\r\n          ID: default highstate\r\n    Function: salt.state\r\n      Result: False\r\n     Comment: Run failed on minions: minion1.example.com, minion2.example.com\r\n     Started: 10:25:50.836611\r\n    Duration: 3700.958 ms\r\n     Changes:\r\n              minion1.example.com:\r\n                  Data failed to compile:\r\n              ----------\r\n                  Rendering SLS 'base:foo.bar' failed: while constructing a mapping\r\n                in \"<unicode string>\", line 1, column 1:\r\n                  prereqs:\r\n                  ^\r\n              found conflicting ID '/usr/local/src/default'\r\n                in \"<unicode string>\", line 741, column 1:\r\n                  /usr/local/src/default:\r\n                  ^\r\n              minion2.example.com:\r\n                  Data failed to compile:\r\n              ----------\r\n                  Rendering SLS 'base:foo.bar' failed: while constructing a mapping\r\n                in \"<unicode string>\", line 1, column 1:\r\n                  prereqs:\r\n                  ^\r\n              found conflicting ID '/usr/local/src/default'\r\n                in \"<unicode string>\", line 741, column 1:\r\n                  /usr/local/src/default:\r\n                  ^\r\n```\r\n\r\nIf I change it to a `salt.function` which calls `state.highstate`, it works as expected.\r\n\r\n### Setup\r\n\r\nIn an orchestrator, I have:\r\n\r\n```yaml\r\n{{ pillar.name }} highstate:\r\n  salt.state:\r\n    - tgt: \"{{ pillar_tgt }}\"\r\n    - tgt_type: pillar\r\n    - highstate: True\r\n    - kwarg:\r\n        pillar:\r\n            only_sites: [{{ pillar.name }}]\r\n    - require:\r\n      - salt: {{ pillar.name }} db\r\n```\r\n\r\n### Versions Report\r\n\r\n```\r\nSalt Version:\r\n           Salt: 2018.3.4\r\n\r\nDependency Versions:\r\n           cffi: Not Installed\r\n       cherrypy: Not Installed\r\n       dateutil: 2.6.1\r\n      docker-py: Not Installed\r\n          gitdb: 2.0.3\r\n      gitpython: 2.1.8\r\n          ioflo: Not Installed\r\n         Jinja2: 2.10\r\n        libgit2: 0.26.0\r\n        libnacl: Not Installed\r\n       M2Crypto: Not Installed\r\n           Mako: Not Installed\r\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\r\n msgpack-python: 0.5.6\r\n   mysql-python: 1.3.10\r\n      pycparser: Not Installed\r\n       pycrypto: 2.6.1\r\n   pycryptodome: Not Installed\r\n         pygit2: 0.26.2\r\n         Python: 3.6.5 (default, Apr  1 2018, 05:46:30)\r\n   python-gnupg: 0.4.1\r\n         PyYAML: 3.12\r\n          PyZMQ: 16.0.2\r\n           RAET: Not Installed\r\n          smmap: 2.0.3\r\n        timelib: Not Installed\r\n        Tornado: 4.5.3\r\n            ZMQ: 4.2.5\r\n\r\nSystem Versions:\r\n           dist: Ubuntu 18.04 bionic\r\n         locale: UTF-8\r\n        machine: x86_64\r\n        release: 4.15.0-1019-aws\r\n         system: Linux\r\n        version: Ubuntu 18.04 bionic\r\n```\r\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question

When using `salt.state` in an orchestrator, I get the following error:

```
----------
          ID: default highstate
    Function: salt.state
      Result: False
     Comment: Run failed on minions: minion1.example.com, minion2.example.com
     Started: 10:25:50.836611
    Duration: 3700.958 ms
     Changes:
              minion1.example.com:
                  Data failed to compile:
              ----------
                  Rendering SLS 'base:foo.bar' failed: while constructing a mapping
                in "<unicode string>", line 1, column 1:
                  prereqs:
                  ^
              found conflicting ID '/usr/local/src/default'
                in "<unicode string>", line 741, column 1:
                  /usr/local/src/default:
                  ^
              minion2.example.com:
                  Data failed to compile:
              ----------
                  Rendering SLS 'base:foo.bar' failed: while constructing a mapping
                in "<unicode string>", line 1, column 1:
                  prereqs:
                  ^
              found conflicting ID '/usr/local/src/default'
                in "<unicode string>", line 741, column 1:
                  /usr/local/src/default:
                  ^
```

If I change it to a `salt.function` which calls `state.highstate`, it works as expected.

### Setup

In an orchestrator, I have:

```yaml
{{ pillar.name }} highstate:
  salt.state:
    - tgt: "{{ pillar_tgt }}"
    - tgt_type: pillar
    - highstate: True
    - kwarg:
        pillar:
            only_sites: [{{ pillar.name }}]
    - require:
      - salt: {{ pillar.name }} db
```

### Versions Report

```
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2018.3.4

Dependency Versions:
           cffi: Not Installed
       cherrypy: Not Installed
       dateutil: 2.6.1
      docker-py: Not Installed
          gitdb: 2.0.3
      gitpython: 2.1.8
          ioflo: Not Installed
         Jinja2: 2.10
        libgit2: 0.26.0
        libnacl: Not Installed
       M2Crypto: Not Installed
           Mako: Not Installed
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.5.6
   mysql-python: 1.3.10
      pycparser: Not Installed
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
   pycryptodome: Not Installed
         pygit2: 0.26.2
         Python: 3.6.5 (default, Apr  1 2018, 05:46:30)
   python-gnupg: 0.4.1
         PyYAML: 3.12
          PyZMQ: 16.0.2
           RAET: Not Installed
          smmap: 2.0.3
        timelib: Not Installed
        Tornado: 4.5.3
            ZMQ: 4.2.5

System Versions:
           dist: Ubuntu 18.04 bionic
         locale: UTF-8
        machine: x86_64
        release: 4.15.0-1019-aws
         system: Linux
        version: Ubuntu 18.04 bionic
```
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "Conflicting IDs when running salt.state orchestrator"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",
            "description": "broken, incorrect, or confusing behavior"
        },
        {
            "name": "P3",
            "description": "Priority 3"
        },
        {
            "name": "severity-medium",
            "description": "3rd level, incorrect or bad functionality, confusing and lacks a work around"
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

{
    "id": 89954798,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/24858",
    "body": "When issuing `salt '*' virt.init name 1 1024 salt://image.img`, I noticed that it was filling the / partition on the hypervisor. The image itself is sparse, or thin provisioned, and using rsync without the --sparse flag results in it shipping 50G, as opposed to 1G, which is the file size on the salt master. \n\nI tried searching the project for sparse to see if it was an option already, to no avail. \nIs this already resolved somehow as well for salt-cloud? \n\nThank you in advance for any feedback you might have.\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question
While poking around modules/gpg for a new feature (#40596) I ran into a regression:
%> git bisect bad
7dc6b64689f5ea48365212dfcebfc4c46ae94607 is the first bad commit
commit 7dc6b64689f5ea48365212dfcebfc4c46ae94607
Author: Pedro Algarvio <pedro@algarvio.me>
Date:   Mon Mar 6 14:20:20 2017 +0000

    No need to call `.keys()` when iterating a dictionary

:040000 040000 24535aff4ae47b6c2a8e9397f05812b30b450fbc 1a8c5d4eb6c1c32320958f04693eec42c4141715 M      salt
:040000 040000 b7b96ed500b52ce8102ad24f6ad0199bb9f432b6 e8646e4e60065bb756b28e474cbbeac0d2a7c784 M      tests

This commit was part of PR #39843

### Steps to Reproduce Issue
``salt -c /tmp/saltdev/etc/salt '*' gpg.receive_keys``
Expected output: usage help
Actual output:
```
saltdev:
    The minion function caused an exception: Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/home/artanicus/salt.git/salt/minion.py", line 1446, in _thread_return
        try:
      File "/home/artanicus/salt.git/salt/executors/direct_call.py", line 28, in execute
        return self.func(*self.args, **self.kwargs)
      File "/home/artanicus/salt.git/salt/modules/gpg.py", line 166, in func_wrapper
        for key in kwargs:
    RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during iteration
```

### Versions Report
%> salt --versions-report
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2016.11.0-946-g7dc6b64
 
Dependency Versions:
           cffi: Not Installed
       cherrypy: Not Installed
       dateutil: Not Installed
          gitdb: Not Installed
      gitpython: Not Installed
          ioflo: Not Installed
         Jinja2: 2.9.6
        libgit2: Not Installed
        libnacl: Not Installed
       M2Crypto: 0.26.0
           Mako: Not Installed
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.4.8
   mysql-python: Not Installed
      pycparser: Not Installed
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
         pygit2: Not Installed
         Python: 2.7.12 (default, Nov 19 2016, 06:48:10)
   python-gnupg: 0.4.0
         PyYAML: 3.12
          PyZMQ: 16.0.2
           RAET: Not Installed
          smmap: Not Installed
        timelib: Not Installed
        Tornado: 4.4.3
            ZMQ: 4.1.6
 
System Versions:
           dist: Ubuntu 16.04 xenial
        machine: x86_64
        release: 4.4.0-51-generic
         system: Linux
        version: Ubuntu 16.04 xenial"
    ],
    "title": [
        "[Bug] modules/gpg regression introduced in PR 39843"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",
            "description": "broken, incorrect, or confusing behavior"
        },
        {
            "name": "fixed-pls-verify",
            "description": "fix is linked, bug author to confirm fix"
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

{
    "id": 59469805,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/21216",
    "body": "Whenever an error occurs within the `rabbitmq_plugin` state it returns a dictionary into the Comment field instead of a sensible error. \n\nAn example of what it would put into this field:\n\n```\n{\"pid\": 8105, \"retcode\": 1, \"stderr\": \"erlexec: HOME must be set\", \"stdout\": \"\"}\n```\n\nPerhaps it should only put the `stderr` (and maybe also `stdout`) content into the Comment field as a string rather than a dictionary.\n\nVersion info:\n\n```\n           Salt: 2014.7.1\n         Python: 2.7.6 (default, Mar 22 2014, 22:59:56)\n         Jinja2: 2.7.2\n       M2Crypto: 0.21.1\n msgpack-python: 0.3.0\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\n       pycrypto: 2.6.1\n        libnacl: Not Installed\n         PyYAML: 3.10\n          ioflo: Not Installed\n          PyZMQ: 14.0.1\n           RAET: Not Installed\n            ZMQ: 4.0.4\n           Mako: 0.9.1\n```\n",

{
    "id": 35212710,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/7387",
    "body": "As pointed out by @dsm054, there are multiple lurking split/partition API requests. Here are the issues and a short summary of what they would do (there are some duplicates here, I've checked off those issues/PRs that have been closed in favor of a related issue):\n- [x] #414: (i think) original issue for these ideas going back 3 years\n- [x] #936: windowing with time-length windows like `pd.rolling_mean(ts, window='30min')` and possibly even arbitrary windows using another column\n- [x] #3066: `split` method on pandas objects, playing around with ideas\n- [x] #3101: a closed PR by @y-p to use the args of lambda to group a frame into views of a sliding window\n- [x] #3685: resampling using the first `n` samples of a bin.\n- [ ] #4059: `np.array_split` style API where you can split a pandas object into a list of `k` groups of possibly unequal size (could be a thin wrapper around `np.array_split`, or more integrated into the pandas DSL). IMO, this issue provides the best starting point for an API. [SO usage](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/24461906/how-can-i-divide-up-a-pandas-dataframe/24462529#24462529)\n- [x] #5494: an API for to allow pandas' `groupby` to have `itertools.groupby` semantics (i.e., preserve the order of duplicated group keys), i.e., `'aabbaa'` would yield groups `['aa', 'bb', 'aa']` rather than `['aaaa', 'bb']`. There'd have to be some changes to the use of `dict` in the groupby backend as noted by @y-p here https://github.com/pydata/pandas/issues/4059#issuecomment-29061036.\n- [ ] #6675: Ability to select ranged groups via another column, like \"select all rows between the values X and Y from column C\", e.g., an \"events\" column where you have a start and end markers and you want to get the data in between the markers. There are a couple of ways you can do this, but it would be nice to have an API for this. This is very similar to #936.\n\nThe [`toolz`](https://github.com/pytoolz/toolz) library has a `partitionby` function that provides a nice way to do some of the splitting on sequences and might provide us with some insight on how to approach the API.\n\ncc @jreback @jorisvandenbossche @hayd @danielballan\n",

{
    "id": 198760058,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/38559",
    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question
`salt-cloud` `scaleway` driver has outdated API URLs which render it unusable. Most requests to API do not return any data and the control of instances seems impossible. It also does not give any error messages as the old API URLs use normal (`200`) status codes.

`salt-cloud` seems to use the old URL (`https://api.cloud.online.net`) when making API calls while scaleway API has been updated to use different URLs, which are based on the region where you server is hosted at. An excerpt from scaleway's documentation regarding API Endpoints:

> ## Request and response 
> 
> Our API works over https and is accessed from several endpoints:
> 
> cp-`<region>`.scaleway.com for Compute Power related actions, where `<region>` is **par1** or **ams1**.

Source: https://developer.scaleway.com/#header-request-and-response

### Setup
contents of `/etc/salt/cloud`:

```yaml
cloud:
  providers:
    my-scaleway:
      access_key: REPLACE_WITH_SCALEWAY_ACCESS_KEY
      token: REPLACE_WITH_SCALEWAY_TOKEN
      driver: scaleway

  profiles:
    scaleway-archlinux:
      provider: my-scaleway
      image: Arch Linux
```


### Steps to Reproduce Issue
1. I have an instance running on Scaleway and provider configured.
2. I run `salt-cloud -l debug -p my-scaleway -F` and get empty results:

```
[DEBUG   ] Reading configuration from /etc/salt/cloud
[DEBUG   ] Missing configuration file: /etc/salt/master
[DEBUG   ] Using cached minion ID from /etc/salt/minion_id: REDACTED
```

{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question
`salt-cloud` `scaleway` driver has outdated API URLs which render it unusable. Most requests to API do not return any data and the control of instances seems impossible. It also does not give any error messages as the old API URLs use normal (`200`) status codes.

`salt-cloud` seems to use the old URL (`https://api.cloud.online.net`) when making API calls while scaleway API has been updated to use different URLs, which are based on the region where you server is hosted at. An excerpt from scaleway's documentation regarding API Endpoints:

> ## Request and response 
> 
> Our API works over https and is accessed from several endpoints:
> 
> cp-`<region>`.scaleway.com for Compute Power related actions, where `<region>` is **par1** or **ams1**.

Source: https://developer.scaleway.com/#header-request-and-response

### Setup
contents of `/etc/salt/cloud`:

```yaml
cloud:
  providers:
    my-scaleway:
      access_key: REPLACE_WITH_SCALEWAY_ACCESS_KEY
      token: REPLACE_WITH_SCALEWAY_TOKEN
      driver: scaleway

  profiles:
    scaleway-archlinux:
      provider: my-scaleway
      image: Arch Linux
```


### Steps to Reproduce Issue
1. I have an instance running on Scaleway and provider configured.
2. I run `salt-cloud -l debug -p my-scaleway -F` and get empty results:

```
[DEBUG   ] Reading configuration from /etc/salt/cloud
[DEBUG   ] Missing configuration file: /etc/salt/master
[DEBUG   ] Using cached minion ID from /etc/salt/minion_id: REDACTED
[DEBUG   ] Reading configuration from /etc/salt/cloud.providers
[DEBUG   ] Reading configuration from /etc/salt/cloud.profiles
[DEBUG   ] Configuration file path: /etc/salt/cloud
[WARNING ] Insecure logging configuration detected! Sensitive data may be logged.
[INFO    ] salt-cloud starting
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad parallels.avail_sizes: 'parallels' __virtual__ returned False
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded parallels.avail_locations
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded proxmox.avail_sizes
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad saltify.destroy: 'saltify.destroy' is not available.
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad saltify.avail_sizes: 'saltify.avail_sizes' is not available.
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad saltify.avail_images: 'saltify.avail_images' is not available.
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad saltify.avail_locations: 'saltify.avail_locations' is not available.
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded rackspace.reboot
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded openstack.list_locations
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded rackspace.list_locations
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad scaleway.optimize_providers: 'scaleway.optimize_providers' is not available.
[DEBUG   ] The 'scaleway' cloud driver is unable to be optimized.
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad parallels.avail_sizes: 'parallels' __virtual__ returned False
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded parallels.avail_locations
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded proxmox.avail_sizes
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad saltify.destroy: 'saltify.destroy' is not available.
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad saltify.avail_sizes: 'saltify.avail_sizes' is not available.
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad saltify.avail_images: 'saltify.avail_images' is not available.
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad saltify.avail_locations: 'saltify.avail_locations' is not available.
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded rackspace.reboot
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded openstack.list_locations
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded rackspace.list_locations
[DEBUG   ] https://api.cloud.online.net/servers/
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded nested.output
```

3. As there is no output (and no error), I notice the printed old API URL, which I decide to change in `salt/cloud/clouds/scaleway.py` file, line `343` from:

```
default='https://api.cloud.online.net'
```

to:

```
default='https://cp-ams1.scaleway.com'
```
(this change is due to my server hosted in AMS1. Should it be in different location, I'd have to change it to something else).

4. After this change, I recompile the file and re-run `salt-cloud -l debug -p my-scaleway -F` again (it results the servers that are running correctly):

```
[DEBUG   ] Reading configuration from /etc/salt/cloud
[DEBUG   ] Missing configuration file: /etc/salt/master
[DEBUG   ] Using cached minion ID from /etc/salt/minion_id: REDACTED
[DEBUG   ] Reading configuration from /etc/salt/cloud.providers
[DEBUG   ] Reading configuration from /etc/salt/cloud.profiles
[DEBUG   ] Configuration file path: /etc/salt/cloud
[WARNING ] Insecure logging configuration detected! Sensitive data may be logged.
[INFO    ] salt-cloud starting
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad parallels.avail_sizes: 'parallels' __virtual__ returned False
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded parallels.avail_locations
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded proxmox.avail_sizes
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad saltify.destroy: 'saltify.destroy' is not available.
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad saltify.avail_sizes: 'saltify.avail_sizes' is not available.
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad saltify.avail_images: 'saltify.avail_images' is not available.
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad saltify.avail_locations: 'saltify.avail_locations' is not available.
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded rackspace.reboot
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded openstack.list_locations
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded rackspace.list_locations
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad scaleway.optimize_providers: 'scaleway.optimize_providers' is not available.
[DEBUG   ] The 'scaleway' cloud driver is unable to be optimized.
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad parallels.avail_sizes: 'parallels' __virtual__ returned False
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded parallels.avail_locations
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded proxmox.avail_sizes
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad saltify.destroy: 'saltify.destroy' is not available.
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad saltify.avail_sizes: 'saltify.avail_sizes' is not available.
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad saltify.avail_images: 'saltify.avail_images' is not available.
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad saltify.avail_locations: 'saltify.avail_locations' is not available.
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded rackspace.reboot
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded openstack.list_locations
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded rackspace.list_locations
[DEBUG   ] https://cp-ams1.scaleway.com/servers/
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded nested.output
my-scaleway:
    ----------
    scaleway:
        ----------
        REDACTED:
            ----------
            arch:
                x86_64
            bootscript:
                ----------
                architecture:
                    x86_64
                
		REST OF OUTPUT IS REDACTED
```

### Versions Report
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2016.11.1
 
Dependency Versions:
           cffi: Not Installed
       cherrypy: Not Installed
       dateutil: Not Installed
          gitdb: Not Installed
      gitpython: Not Installed
          ioflo: Not Installed
         Jinja2: 2.8.1
        libgit2: Not Installed
        libnacl: Not Installed
       M2Crypto: Not Installed
           Mako: Not Installed
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.4.8
   mysql-python: Not Installed
      pycparser: Not Installed
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
         pygit2: Not Installed
         Python: 2.7.13 (default, Dec 21 2016, 07:16:46)
   python-gnupg: Not Installed
         PyYAML: 3.12
          PyZMQ: 16.0.2
           RAET: Not Installed
          smmap: Not Installed
        timelib: Not Installed
        Tornado: 4.4.2
            ZMQ: 4.1.6
 
System Versions:
           dist:   
        machine: x86_64
        release: 4.8.15-2-ck-ivybridge
         system: Linux
        version: Not Installed
 
salt-cloud v0.8.11"
    ],
    "title": [
        "salt-cloud scaleway driver API URLs (api_root setting) missing in the docs"
    ],

{
    "id": 124578914,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/30123",
    "body": "`grains['oscodename']` seems to be parsed incorrectly from `/etc/os-release` on Debian testing, due to the slash in the codename.\n\nFor Debian-based distros (or just Debian), the codename should probably be pulled from `/etc/debian_version` since it's much easier to parse without error.\n\n```\noptix2000@inazuma ~ % cat /etc/debian_version\nstretch/sid\noptix2000@inazuma ~ % cat /etc/os-release\nPRETTY_NAME=\"Debian GNU/Linux stretch/sid\"\nNAME=\"Debian GNU/Linux\"\nID=debian\nHOME_URL=\"https://www.debian.org/\"\nSUPPORT_URL=\"https://www.debian.org/support\"\nBUG_REPORT_URL=\"https://bugs.debian.org/\"\noptix2000@inazuma ~ % sudo salt-call grains.get oscodename\nlocal:\n    sid\noptix2000@inazuma ~ % salt-call --versions-report\nSalt Version:\n           Salt: 2015.8.3\n\nDependency Versions:\n         Jinja2: 2.8\n       M2Crypto: Not Installed\n           Mako: 1.0.3\n         PyYAML: 3.11\n          PyZMQ: 14.4.0\n         Python: 2.7.11 (default, Dec  9 2015, 00:29:25)\n           RAET: Not Installed\n        Tornado: 4.2.1\n            ZMQ: 4.0.5\n           cffi: Not Installed\n       cherrypy: Not Installed\n       dateutil: 2.4.2\n          gitdb: Not Installed\n      gitpython: Not Installed\n          ioflo: Not Installed\n        libnacl: Not Installed\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\n msgpack-python: 0.4.6\n   mysql-python: 1.3.7\n      pycparser: Not Installed\n       pycrypto: 2.6.1\n         pygit2: Not Installed\n   python-gnupg: Not Installed\n          smmap: Not Installed\n        timelib: Not Installed\n\nSystem Versions:\n           dist: debian stretch/sid\n        machine: x86_64\n        release: 4.3.0-1-amd64\n         system: debian stretch/sid\n```\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "`grains['oscodename']` seems to be parsed incorrectly from `/etc/os-release` on Debian testing, due to the slash in the codename.

For Debian-based distros (or just Debian), the codename should probably be pulled from `/etc/debian_version` since it's much easier to parse without error.

```
optix2000@inazuma ~ % cat /etc/debian_version
stretch/sid
optix2000@inazuma ~ % cat /etc/os-release
PRETTY_NAME="Debian GNU/Linux stretch/sid"
NAME="Debian GNU/Linux"
ID=debian
HOME_URL="https://www.debian.org/"
SUPPORT_URL="https://www.debian.org/support"
BUG_REPORT_URL="https://bugs.debian.org/"
optix2000@inazuma ~ % sudo salt-call grains.get oscodename
local:
    sid
optix2000@inazuma ~ % salt-call --versions-report
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2015.8.3

Dependency Versions:
         Jinja2: 2.8
       M2Crypto: Not Installed
           Mako: 1.0.3
         PyYAML: 3.11
          PyZMQ: 14.4.0
         Python: 2.7.11 (default, Dec  9 2015, 00:29:25)
           RAET: Not Installed
        Tornado: 4.2.1
            ZMQ: 4.0.5
           cffi: Not Installed
       cherrypy: Not Installed
       dateutil: 2.4.2
          gitdb: Not Installed
      gitpython: Not Installed
          ioflo: Not Installed
        libnacl: Not Installed
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.4.6
   mysql-python: 1.3.7
      pycparser: Not Installed
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
         pygit2: Not Installed
   python-gnupg: Not Installed
          smmap: Not Installed
        timelib: Not Installed

System Versions:
           dist: debian stretch/sid
        machine: x86_64
        release: 4.3.0-1-amd64
         system: debian stretch/sid
```
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "grains['oscodename'] incorrect for Debian testing."
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",
            "description": "broken, incorrect, or confusing behavior"
        },
        {
            "name": "P2",
            "description": "Priority 2"
        },
        {
            "name": "Platform",
            "description": "Relates to OS, containers, platform-based utilities like FS, system based apps"
        },
        {
            "name": "severity-medium",
            "description": "3rd level, incorrect or bad functionality, confusing and lacks a work around"
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/25980",
    "body": "I'm trying to run a salt-master / salt-minion setup on a single machine (freebsd 9) using ipv6. This is continuously failing with \"Invalid argument\". \n\nMaster config file: http://paste2.org/ZhFypIas\nMinion config file: http://paste2.org/mwmB30kK\n\nMaster log level all: http://paste2.org/jwmBBssM\nMinion log level all: http://paste2.org/bbm59AYy\n\nWe've hit this on freebsd infrastructure. I've created a clean freebsd-9 VM just to test this, and hit it as well. Let me know if any info is needed\n",

{
    "id": 56595612,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/20404",
    "body": "Hi\n\nI stumbled on a problem when trying to use the `key_url` parameter of the \"pkgrepo.managed\" state: the [documentation](http://docs.saltstack.com/en/latest/ref/states/all/salt.states.pkgrepo.html#salt.states.pkgrepo.managed) describes this parameter as \"URL to retrieve a GPG key from\", although looking at the [actual code](https://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/cefb78efe93e494087f1eb0ce92e8fc8b7b5ef16/salt/modules/aptpkg.py#L1556) behind the feature it calls the `apt-key add` command and passes the value of the setting \u2013 which misleads to think it can be a URL, but `apt-key` only accepts local file paths.\n\nI suggest fixing the documentation to clarify this, as it took me more than a hour trying to find out why I still got invalid signature issues although I've specified the _URL_ where the signing public key could be fetched from ;)\n",
    "user": {
        "id": 1122379,
        "url": "https://api.github.com/users/falzm",
        "type": "User",
        "login": "falzm",
        "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjExMjIzNzk=",
        "html_url": "https://github.com/falzm",

{
    "id": 180960207,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/36772",
    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\n\nIn the same way that one can configure multiple backend providers for states, pillars, etc, I'd like to have alternate sources for cloud profiles and providers. Salt-cloud is the only component I know of that requires that its data come from YAML files on the local filesystem. Let's open this area up to customization and see what the community does with it.\n\nHere is one use case I know of from a company nearby. They found that they were essentially maintaining a profile of every possible combination of 4 different variables. So they wrote a program to calculate a matrix of those 4 dimensions and generate their cloud profiles file automatically.\n",
    "user": {
        "id": 6018668,
        "url": "https://api.github.com/users/amendlik",

{
    "id": 606462681,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/33770",
    "body": "- [X] I have checked that this issue has not already been reported.

- [X] I have confirmed this bug exists on the latest version of pandas.

- [X] (optional) I have confirmed this bug exists on the master branch of pandas.

---

#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example

Prerequisites:
```console
$ pip install pandas numpy memoized-property
$ pip install git+https://github.com/frreiss/text-extensions-for-pandas
```

Reproduce the problem, using [`TensorArray`](https://github.com/frreiss/text-extensions-for-pandas/blob/master/text_extensions_for_pandas/array/tensor.py), our extension type for storing tensors in a Pandas series:
```python
>>> import pandas as pd
>>> import numpy as np
>>> import text_extensions_for_pandas as tp
>>> # Integers work
    int_tensors = np.array([[1, 2], [3, 4]])
    int_tensor_series = pd.Series(tp.TensorArray(int_tensors))
    int_tensor_series

0   [1 2]
1   [3 4]
dtype: TensorType

>>> # Boolean values don't work
    bool_tensors = np.array([[True, False], [False, True]])
    bool_tensor_series = pd.Series(tp.TensorArray(bool_tensors))
    bool_tensor_series
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
~/pd/covid-notebooks/env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/IPython/core/formatters.py in __call__(self, obj)
    700                 type_pprinters=self.type_printers,
    701                 deferred_pprinters=self.deferred_printers)
--> 702             printer.pretty(obj)
    703             printer.flush()
    704             return stream.getvalue()

[...many lines of stack trace...]

~/pd/covid-notebooks/env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pandas/io/formats/format.py in _format_strings(self)
   1255         fmt_values = []
   1256         for i, v in enumerate(vals):
-> 1257             if not is_float_type[i] and leading_space:
   1258                 fmt_values.append(" {v}".format(v=_format(v)))
   1259             elif is_float_type[i]:

ValueError: The truth value of an array with more than one element is ambiguous. Use a.any() or a.all()

```

#### Problem description

`Series.__repr__()` invokes `ExtensionArrayFormatter` to render extension types. If the individual elements managed by an ExtensionArray are numpy arrays (or slices of a larger numpy array), then  `ExtensionArrayFormatter` uses Pandas' facilities for rendering numpy arrays. These facilities comprise the base class `GenericArrayFormatter` and subclasses such as `FloatArrayFormatter` for handling specific types (see `pandas/io/formats/format.py`). The formatters for numeric types can render numpy arrays with more than one dimension, but the base class `GenericArrayFormatter` cannot. The limitation appears to be an oversight. I will submit a small pull request with a fix in a few minutes.

#### Expected Output

The above code should output something like this:

```python
0   [True False]
1   [False True]
dtype: TensorType
```

#### Output of ``pd.show_versions()``

    "body": "EDIT: now the replacement of #11132\r\n\r\nAn alternative to #11132, much more following its logic, but (I think) clearer. Mostly for @mattip to look at. {

        "### Description of Issue
creation of a new certificate failed , at the first execution .

```
    Function: acme.cert
        Name: h
      Result: False
     Comment: An exception occurred in this state: Traceback (most recent call last):
                File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/salt/state.py", line 1981, in call
                  **cdata['kwargs'])
                File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/salt/loader.py", line 1977, in wrapper
                  return f(*args, **kwargs)
                File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/salt/states/acme.py", line 141, in cert
                  ret['changes'] = salt.utils.dictdiffer.deep_diff(current_certificate, new_certificate)
                File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/salt/utils/dictdiffer.py", line 54, in deep_diff
                  new = copy.deepcopy(new)
                File "/usr/lib/python3.7/copy.py", line 150, in deepcopy
                  y = copier(x, memo)
                File "/usr/lib/python3.7/copy.py", line 240, in _deepcopy_dict
                  y[deepcopy(key, memo)] = deepcopy(value, memo)
                File "/usr/lib/python3.7/copy.py", line 169, in deepcopy
                  rv = reductor(4)
               TypeError: can't pickle dict_keys objects
    Started: 05:44:34.273018
   Duration: 4196.963 ms
 
```


### Setup
(Please provide relevant configs and/or SLS files (Be sure to remove sensitive info).)

```
new-cert-for-bots:
  acme.cert:
    - name: {{ pillar['x509_hostname'] }}
    - email:  {{ pillar['x509_email'] }}
    - http_01_port: 8080
    - http_01_address: 127.0.0.1

```
### Steps to Reproduce Issue

a web server that proxy to 8080 , with nginx :
  
```
      location /.well-known/acme-challenge/ {
           proxy_set_header        Host $host;
           proxy_pass              http://127.0.0.1:8080;
        }

```

{
    "id": 80946447,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/24134",
    "body": "The issue I have here is that when I am using custom file_repos locations winrepo does not get searched. winrepo is only searched if my state file is in base.\n\nI've looked through the salt-users mailing list and reported issues on salt, came across #10894 which sounds similar. I am trying to install \"Filezilla Server\" using saltstack onto a box onto a minion that is part of the test environment. This minion has the filezilla/init.sls defined in the test file_roots and it its located here things fail. If I move the statefile to base then things work fine.\n\nThere is perhaps some misunderstanding I have on how the file_roots relates to winrepo. Maybe I need to add extra locations of winrepo but I can't see it documented anywhere.\n\nMy winrepo is configured as default\n\n```\nwin_repo: '/srv/salt/win/repo'\nwin_repo_mastercachefile: '/srv/salt/win/repo/winrepo.p'\n```\n\nMy /etc/salt/master.d/file_roots.conf\n\n```\nfile_roots:\n  base:\n    - /srv/salt\n  development:\n    - /srv/salt/development/states\n  test:\n    - /srv/salt/test/states\n  acceptance:\n    - /srv/salt/acceptance/states\n  production:\n    - /srv/salt/production/states\n  lab:\n    - /srv/salt/lab/states\n[root@sahsalt9358 master.d]#\n```\n\nWhen filezilla/init.sls is sitting in my file_roots test section it doesnt seem to search winrepo\n\n```\n----------\n          ID: filezilla\n    Function: pkg.installed\n      Result: False\n     Comment: An exception occurred in this state: Traceback (most recent call last):\n                File \"C:\\salt\\bin\\lib\\site-packages\\salt\\state.py\", line 1563, in call\n                  **cdata['kwargs'])\n                File \"C:\\salt\\bin\\lib\\site-packages\\salt\\states\\pkg.py\", line 947, in installed\n                  **kwargs)\n                File \"C:\\salt\\bin\\lib\\site-packages\\salt\\modules\\win_pkg.py\", line 540, in install\n                  __salt__['cp.hash_file'](cached_pkg):\n                File \"C:\\salt\\bin\\lib\\site-packages\\salt\\modules\\cp.py\", line 639, in hash_file\n                  return __context__['cp.fileclient'].hash_file(path, saltenv)\n                File \"C:\\salt\\bin\\lib\\site-packages\\salt\\fileclient.py\", line 1145, in hash_file\n                  path = self._check_proto(path)\n                File \"C:\\salt\\bin\\lib\\site-packages\\salt\\fileclient.py\", line 66, in _check_proto\n                  if not path.startswith('salt://'):\n              AttributeError: 'bool' object has no attribute 'startswith'\n     Started: 13:59:25.416000\n    Duration: 1250.0 ms\n     Changes:\n----------\n```\n\nWhen filezilla/init.sls is moved to base it works (ignore the fact that it says failed, thats another issue, it does correctly install the binary)\n\n```\n----------\n          ID: filezilla\n    Function: pkg.installed\n      Result: False\n     Comment: The following packages failed to install/update: filezilla=0.9.51\n     Started: 14:05:15.216000\n    Duration: 5129.0 ms\n     Changes:\n----------\n```\n\nsalt-master\n\n```\n[root@salt-master salt]# salt --versions-report\n           Salt: 2015.5.0\n         Python: 2.7.5 (default, Jun 17 2014, 18:11:42)\n         Jinja2: 2.7.3\n       M2Crypto: 0.21.1\n msgpack-python: 0.4.6\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\n       pycrypto: 2.6.1\n        libnacl: Not Installed\n         PyYAML: 3.11\n          ioflo: Not Installed\n          PyZMQ: 14.3.1\n           RAET: Not Installed\n            ZMQ: 3.2.5\n           Mako: Not Installed\n[root@sahsalt9358 salt]#\n```\n\nwindows-minion\n\n```\nc:\\salt>salt-call.bat --versions-report\n           Salt: 2015.5.0\n         Python: 2.7.8 (default, Jun 30 2014, 16:08:48) [MSC v.1500 64 bit (AMD64)]\n         Jinja2: 2.7.3\n       M2Crypto: 0.21.1\n msgpack-python: 0.4.5\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\n       pycrypto: 2.6\n        libnacl: Not Installed\n         PyYAML: 3.11\n          ioflo: Not Installed\n          PyZMQ: 14.5.0\n           RAET: Not Installed\n            ZMQ: 4.0.5\n           Mako: Not Installed\n\nc:\\salt>\n```\n\nMy filezilla winrepo config\n\n```\n[root@salt-master repo]# cat filezilla/init.sls\nfilezilla:\n  0.9.51:\n    installer: 'salt://win/repo/filezilla/FileZilla_Server-0_9_51.exe'\n    full_name: 'Filezilla Server 0.9.51'\n    locale: en_US\n    reboot: False\n    install_flags: ' /S '\n    uninstaller: 'C:\\Program Files (x86)\\FileZilla Server\\Uninstall.exe'\n    uninstall_flags: ' /S'\n    refresh: true\n[root@salt-master repo]#\n```\n\nMy filezilla/init.sls\n\n```\nfilezilla:\n  pkg.installed:\n    - normalize: False\n#    - name: 'FileZilla Server'\n#    - name: 'Filezilla Server 0.9.51'\n#    - refresh: True\n\n'C:\\Program Files (x86)\\FileZilla Server\\FileZilla Server.xml':\n  file.managed:\n    - source: salt://filezilla/filezilla_server.xml\n    - template: jinja\n\nfilezillas:\n  service.running:\n    - name: 'FileZilla Server'\n    - enable: True\n#    - require:\n#      - pkg: filezilla\n```\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "The issue I have here is that when I am using custom file_repos locations winrepo does not get searched. winrepo is only searched if my state file is in base.

I've looked through the salt-users mailing list and reported issues on salt, came across #10894 which sounds similar. I am trying to install "Filezilla Server" using saltstack onto a box onto a minion that is part of the test environment. This minion has the filezilla/init.sls defined in the test file_roots and it its located here things fail. If I move the statefile to base then things work fine.

There is perhaps some misunderstanding I have on how the file_roots relates to winrepo. Maybe I need to add extra locations of winrepo but I can't see it documented anywhere.

My winrepo is configured as default

```
win_repo: '/srv/salt/win/repo'
win_repo_mastercachefile: '/srv/salt/win/repo/winrepo.p'
```

My /etc/salt/master.d/file_roots.conf

```
file_roots:
  base:
    - /srv/salt
  development:
    - /srv/salt/development/states
  test:
    - /srv/salt/test/states
  acceptance:
    - /srv/salt/acceptance/states
  production:
    - /srv/salt/production/states
  lab:
    - /srv/salt/lab/states
[root@sahsalt9358 master.d]#
```

When filezilla/init.sls is sitting in my file_roots test section it doesnt seem to search winrepo

```
----------
          ID: filezilla
    Function: pkg.installed
      Result: False
     Comment: An exception occurred in this state: Traceback (most recent call last):
                File "C:\salt\bin\lib\site-packages\salt\state.py", line 1563, in call
                  **cdata['kwargs'])
                File "C:\salt\bin\lib\site-packages\salt\states\pkg.py", line 947, in installed
                  **kwargs)
                File "C:\salt\bin\lib\site-packages\salt\modules\win_pkg.py", line 540, in install
                  __salt__['cp.hash_file'](cached_pkg):
                File "C:\salt\bin\lib\site-packages\salt\modules\cp.py", line 639, in hash_file
                  return __context__['cp.fileclient'].hash_file(path, saltenv)
                File "C:\salt\bin\lib\site-packages\salt\fileclient.py", line 1145, in hash_file
                  path = self._check_proto(path)
                File "C:\salt\bin\lib\site-packages\salt\fileclient.py", line 66, in _check_proto
                  if not path.startswith('salt://'):
              AttributeError: 'bool' object has no attribute 'startswith'
     Started: 13:59:25.416000
    Duration: 1250.0 ms
     Changes:
----------
```

When filezilla/init.sls is moved to base it works (ignore the fact that it says failed, thats another issue, it does correctly install the binary)

```
----------
          ID: filezilla
    Function: pkg.installed
      Result: False
     Comment: The following packages failed to install/update: filezilla=0.9.51
     Started: 14:05:15.216000
    Duration: 5129.0 ms
     Changes:
----------
```

salt-master

```
[root@salt-master salt]# salt --versions-report
           Salt: 2015.5.0
         Python: 2.7.5 (default, Jun 17 2014, 18:11:42)
         Jinja2: 2.7.3
       M2Crypto: 0.21.1
 msgpack-python: 0.4.6
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
        libnacl: Not Installed
         PyYAML: 3.11
          ioflo: Not Installed
          PyZMQ: 14.3.1
           RAET: Not Installed
            ZMQ: 3.2.5
           Mako: Not Installed
[root@sahsalt9358 salt]#
```

windows-minion

```
c:\salt>salt-call.bat --versions-report
           Salt: 2015.5.0
         Python: 2.7.8 (default, Jun 30 2014, 16:08:48) [MSC v.1500 64 bit (AMD64)]
         Jinja2: 2.7.3
       M2Crypto: 0.21.1
 msgpack-python: 0.4.5

           RAET: Not Installed
            ZMQ: 4.0.5
           Mako: Not Installed

c:\salt>
```

My filezilla winrepo config

```
[root@salt-master repo]# cat filezilla/init.sls
filezilla:
  0.9.51:
    installer: 'salt://win/repo/filezilla/FileZilla_Server-0_9_51.exe'
    full_name: 'Filezilla Server 0.9.51'
    locale: en_US
    reboot: False
    install_flags: ' /S '
    uninstaller: 'C:\Program Files (x86)\FileZilla Server\Uninstall.exe'
    uninstall_flags: ' /S'
    refresh: true
[root@salt-master repo]#
```

My filezilla/init.sls

```
filezilla:
  pkg.installed:
    - normalize: False
#    - name: 'FileZilla Server'
#    - name: 'Filezilla Server 0.9.51'
#    - refresh: True

'C:\Program Files (x86)\FileZilla Server\FileZilla Server.xml':
  file.managed:
    - source: salt://filezilla/filezilla_server.xml
    - template: jinja

filezillas:
  service.running:
    - name: 'FileZilla Server'
    - enable: True
#    - require:
#      - pkg: filezilla
```

{
    "id": 194284297,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/8355",
    "body": "On Windows, with Python 3.5; if using the setting `compiler=mingw32` (in for instance `setup.cfg`) and then building with `python3 setup.py develop`, the build will end with the error message:\r\n\r\n    ValueError: Unknown MS Compiler version 1900\r\n\r\nbecause the version string that is compiled into Python 3.5 indicates that it is built with Microsoft Visual Studio 2015, and this is unknown to the list coded into the distutils module.\r\n\r\nThis is unfortunate, as it precludes using the easily accessible MinGW distribution's free GNU Fortran compiler to build extensions.\r\n\r\nThis changeset adds support for the runtime used in Python 3.5. It is tested with WinPython 3.5.2.2 and MinGW 6.2.0 (win32, seh, rt-v5). It should be noted that the resulting .pyd still has a dependency on MSVCRT.DLL (and not VCRUNTIME140), but so does PYTHON35.DLL indirectly through WS2_32.DLL.",

{
    "id": 13151379,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/3337",
    "body": "Hi all, \n\nafter having updated my local branch with the current dev master ( pd.**version** == '0.11.0rc1' -- compiling under Mac OS 10.8 went smoothly) some of my scripts in which I handle large data frames (2.6 million rows, 10 columns) stopped working. \nIt turned out that accessing the df's repr method but also looking up docstrings seems to make ipython unresponsive and creates the impression as if it takes forever.\n\nThis little snippet reproduces the error with fake data ('tested' with EPD Python and IPython 7.2 (32-bit)):\n\n``` Python\nimport numpy as np\nimport pandas as pd\n\ndata  = np.random.random((3000000, 10))\ndf = pd.DataFrame(data)\n\nprint df  # does the same as `df.__repr__()` or `df?`\n```\n\nCan anyone confirm this?\nIt must have been some of the more recent changes as I did not have trouble with this earlier.\nAny pointers and comments are highly welcome.\n\nCheers,\nDenis\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "Hi all, 

after having updated my local branch with the current dev master ( pd.**version** == '0.11.0rc1' -- compiling under Mac OS 10.8 went smoothly) some of my scripts in which I handle large data frames (2.6 million rows, 10 columns) stopped working. 
It turned out that accessing the df's repr method but also looking up docstrings seems to make ipython unresponsive and creates the impression as if it takes forever.

This little snippet reproduces the error with fake data ('tested' with EPD Python and IPython 7.2 (32-bit)):

``` Python
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

data  = np.random.random((3000000, 10))
df = pd.DataFrame(data)

print df  # does the same as `df.__repr__()` or `df?`
```

Can anyone confirm this?
It must have been some of the more recent changes as I did not have trouble with this earlier.
Any pointers and comments are highly welcome.

Cheers,
Denis
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "FIX? df.__repr__ takes for ever with big data"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",
            "description": null
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}
